Back:
Meaning: Make/let/have someone do something (causative)

Grammar:
• AVst게 하다
• AVst게 했다

Usage: Used to express causation - making, letting, or having someone do something. The subject causes or allows another person to perform an action. Can express both permission (let) and compulsion (make) depending on context.

Meaning: whether to... or to... (deliberation between options)

Grammar:
• AVst(을,ㄹ)지 AVst(을,ㄹ)지 ____

Usage: Expresses indecision or uncertainty between two or more mutually exclusive options. Often followed by 모르다 (don't know) or 고민하다 (worry/deliberate).

Meaning: Partial Acknowledgment

Grammar:
• Vst기는 하다.
• Vst긴 하다.

Usage: In the form 기는/긴 하다, the speaker acknowledges that something is true or is indeed the case. It is often followed by -지만 or -는데/ㄴ데 grammar to form a partial acknowledgment with an objection.

Meaning: It seems like, it appears that (conjecture based on observation)

Grammar:
• AVst나 보다
• (있,없)나 보다
• DVst(은가,ㄴ가) 보다
• Vst(었,았,였)나 보다
• N인가 보다

Usage: Used to express conjecture or assumption based on indirect evidence or observation. The speaker infers something from what they've seen, heard, or experienced. Less certain than direct observation with -네요, but more certain than pure speculation with -겠-.

Meaning: I think that..., I believe that...

Grammar:
• AVst(는,ㄴ)다고 생각하다
• DVst다고 생각하다
• Vst(었,았,였)다고 생각하다
• Vst(을,ㄹ) 거라고 생각하다
• N(이)라고 생각하다

Usage: Used to express one's opinion, thought, or belief about something. Converts a statement into reported speech followed by the verb 생각하다 (to think). Commonly used to soften assertions or express personal viewpoints politely.

Meaning: If (it is the case that)..., supposing that...

Grammar:
• AVst(는,ㄴ)다면 ____
• DVst다면 ____
• Vst(었,았,였)다면 ____
• N(이)라면 ____

Usage: A conditional form that combines declarative ending -(는)다 with conditional -면. Used to present hypothetical situations or suppositions, often about factual statements or things you've heard. More formal than simple -(으)면 and often used when the condition is based on reported information or general facts.

Meaning: I heard that..., they say that... (seeking confirmation)

Grammar:
• AVst(는,ㄴ)다면서(요)
• DVst다면서(요)
• Vst(었,았,였)다면서(요)
• Vst(을,ㄹ) 거라면서(요)
• N(이)라면서(요)

Usage: Used to confirm or verify information that the speaker has heard from someone else. Often carries the nuance of "Isn't it true that...?" or "I heard that... is that right?" Combines reported speech -(는)다고 with -면서 (while/even though) to create a confirmation-seeking question.

Meaning: They say..., I heard that... (casual reported speech)

Grammar:
• AVst(는,ㄴ)대요
• DVst대요
• Vst(었,았,였)대요
• Vst(을,ㄹ) 거래요
• N(이)래요

Usage: A contracted form of -(는)다고 해요, used to relay information heard from others in casual conversation. More informal than the full form and commonly used in everyday speech to share news, gossip, or secondhand information.

Meaning: tend to, on the {adjective} side, rather, fairly

Grammar:
• AVst는 편이다
• DVst(은,ㄴ) 편이다
• AVst(은,ㄴ) 편이다

Usage: Used to express general tendencies or relative positioning on a spectrum. Softens absolute statements - makes them more moderate/diplomatic.

Notes:
• Cannot be used with extreme absolutes or binary states (e.g., death, existence)
• Action verbs need to have a quantity modifier before the verb: 자주, 정도면,

Meaning: Even though, despite the fact that

Grammar:
• AVst는데도 ____
• (있,없)는데도 ____
• DVst(은,ㄴ)데도 ____
• Vst(었,았,였)데도 ____

Usage: Expresses contrast or unexpectedness - despite the situation in the first clause, something contrary happens in the second clause. Stronger than simple -는데 as it emphasizes that the second clause is surprising or contrary to expectations. Combines -(는)데 with 도 (also/even).

Meaning: do and leave (in that state), do in advance (for later use)

Grammar:
• N(을,를) AVst(어,아,여) 놓다.

Usage: Emphasizes preparation, completion, or the resulting state being maintained. Implies the result is useful or intentional for future reference.

Meaning: looks like, appears to be

Grammar:
• DVst(어,아,여) 보이다.
• DVst(었,았,였)어 보이다.

Usage: Expresses visual appearance or impression based on what the speaker sees. The observer is making a judgment based on visual observation.

Notes:
• Subject is usually third person

Meaning: Continuing or resultant state

Grammar:
• N(이,가) AVst(어,아,여) 있다.

Usage: Emphasizes the continuing state resulting from an action rather than the action itself.

Notes:
• Only works with certain action verbs that can result in a maintained state
• Compatible verbs: 앉다, 서다, 입다, 쓰다, 신다, 놓다, 걸다, etc.
• NOT compatible with momentary or consumption verbs: *먹어 있다, *가 있다

Meaning: Perhaps because..., maybe it's because...

Grammar:
• Vst(어,아,여)서 그런지 ____
• N(어,아,여)서 그런지 ____

Usage: Used to suggest a possible reason or cause for something, with some uncertainty. The speaker is speculating that the situation in the first clause might be the reason for the result in the second clause. More tentative than simple -어서, as 그런지 adds the nuance of "I'm not entirely sure, but maybe..."

Meaning: should, ought to (casual agreement/acknowledgment)

Grammar:
• Vst(어,아,여)야지요.
• Vst(었,았,였)어야지요.
• N(이)어야지요.

Usage: More casual and conversational than -(어,아,여)야 하다/되다. Often expresses agreement with an obvious truth or acknowledgment. More gentle than -(어,아,여)야 돼 (must/have to).

Meaning: After doing..., when I/someone did... (then discovered)

Grammar:
• AVst(었,았,였)더니 ____

Usage: Indicates that after completing the action in the first clause, the speaker discovered or experienced the result in the second clause. Often expresses surprise, discovery, or an unexpected outcome. The subject of the first clause is typically the speaker (first person) when used with action verbs.

Meaning: Would have, must have (past conjecture/counterfactual)

Grammar:
• Vst(었,았,였)을 것이다

Usage: Used to make conjectures about past events or to express counterfactual situations (what would have happened). Can indicate: (1) supposition about what probably happened in the past, or (2) hypothetical outcomes in past conditional contexts. Combines past tense with the future modifier and 것이다 to create past speculation or counterfactual meaning.

Meaning: Upon doing/when I did (then discovered/realized)

Grammar:
• AVst(으)니까 ____

Usage: used with an action verb to state that the fact contained in the second sentence was discovered as a result of the action in the first sentence

Meaning: was just about to (do something)

Grammar:
• AVst(으)려던 참이었다

Usage: Expresses that you were on the verge of doing something (but haven't yet). Often implies the action was interrupted or hasn't happened yet. Used when explaining timing or why something didn't happen.

Notes:
• Subject must be capable of intention

Meaning: In order to, if you want to (with time expressions)

Grammar:
• AVst(으)려면 __시간(남았다, 더 있어야 하다, 멀다)__

Usage: A specific usage of -(으)려면 that appears with time expressions to indicate how much time is needed or remains before something can be accomplished. Often used with expressions like 시간이 남다 (time remains), 더 있어야 하다 (need more time), or 멀다 (far away/long time).

Meaning: While/even though, despite doing (simultaneous contrast)

Grammar:
• Vst(으)면서도 ____
• Vst(었,았,였)으면서도 ____
• N(이)면서도 ____

Usage: Expresses that despite the situation or action in the first clause (which might normally prevent or contradict the second), the second clause still occurs. Combines -(으)면서 (while) with 도 (even/also) to create a concessive meaning stronger than simple -(으)면서. Often used to express contradiction or unexpected simultaneous states.

Meaning: Almost, nearly (did something undesirable)

Grammar:
• AVst(을,ㄹ) 뻔하다

Usage: Expresses that something almost happened but didn't - typically used for negative or undesirable outcomes that were narrowly avoided. Conveys relief that the action didn't actually occur. Common in phrases like 죽을 뻔했다 (almost died) or 늦을 뻔했다 (almost was late).

Meaning: Only, just, nothing but

Grammar:
• Vst(을,ㄹ) 뿐이다
• Vst(었,았,였)을 뿐이다
• N일 뿐이다

Usage: Emphasizes limitation or exclusivity - "this and nothing more." Can express either resignation ("I can only...") or minimization ("I just..."). More formal/literary than -만.

Meaning: Might, may, could possibly (uncertainty)

Grammar:
• Vst(을,ㄹ)지도 모르다
• Vst(었,았,였)지도 모르다
• N일지도 모르다

Usage: Expresses possibility or uncertainty about future events or situations. Literally means "don't know whether," indicating the speaker considers something possible but is uncertain. Softer and less confident than -(을)ㄹ 것이다. The 도 (even/also) adds emphasis to the uncertainty.

Meaning: Such as, like, or (listing examples)

Grammar:
• N1(이)라든가 N2 (같은,처럼) N3

Usage: Used to list examples from a larger category, similar to "such as" or "like" in English. Often appears in patterns with 같은 (like) or 처럼 (as) to introduce representative examples. Can be used with multiple items to create a non-exhaustive list.

Meaning: After doing, once finished

Grammar:
• AVst고 나서 ____

Usage: Indicates that one action is completed before another action begins. Emphasizes the completion of the first action more strongly than simple -고. The 나서 adds the nuance that the first action must be finished before proceeding.

Meaning: After doing, having done (formal sequence)

Grammar:
• AVst고서 ____

Usage: Indicates sequential actions where the first action precedes the second. More formal and literary than -고 나서. Often emphasizes that the first action is a necessary prerequisite or that there's a logical connection between the two actions.

Meaning: For the purpose of, for the sake of, in order to

Grammar:
• AVst기 위해서 ____
• N(을,를) 위해서 ____

Usage: Used when doing something to achieve a goal or for a specific purpose.

Meaning: Easy to (do), prone to

Grammar:
• AVst기가 쉽다

Usage: Expresses that something is easy to do or happens easily. Often used to describe actions that occur readily or frequently, particularly negative actions or undesirable situations. The subject experiences or performs the action easily.

Notes:
• Typically used to say that it's easy to do a negative action
• Can replace 쉽다 with 어렵다, 좋다, 나쁘다, 곤란하다, 등

Meaning: Gentle refutation

Grammar:
• Vst기는(요).

Usage: Expression is used to politely refute or disagree with the other person's statement. Used in response to a compliment to show modesty. Can also be used lightly criticize or scold someone.

Meaning: only do, just do, do nothing but

Grammar:
• Vst기만 하다.
• Vst(었,았,였)기만 하다.

Usage: Emphasizes exclusivity - this action/state and nothing else. Often has a negative connotation when criticizing someone's behavior. Stronger emphasis than just -만 (only).

Meaning: Instead of, in place of, in exchange for

Grammar:
• AVst는 대신에 ____

Usage: Indicates substitution or exchange - one action or situation replaces another. Used when choosing to do something different instead of the expected or mentioned action. Can express trade-offs, compromises, or alternative choices.

Meaning: I noticed/saw that..., when I...(providing background context)

Grammar:
• Vst던데 ____
• Vst(었,았,였)던데 ____

Usage: Combines -던 (past observation/experience) with -는데 (background context) to recall and share a past observation or experience as context for what follows. Used to bring up something the speaker witnessed or experienced, often leading to a question, suggestion, or related comment.

Notes:
• If the action verb is in the first part of the sentence, a first-person subject cannot be used

Meaning: You know that..., as you know (shared knowledge)

Grammar:
• Vst잖아(요)
• Vst(었,았,였)잖아(요)
• N(이)잖아(요)

Usage: Used to remind someone of information that both speaker and listener already know, or to assert something as obvious or well-known. Can express explanation, justification, or mild reproach. Contracted form of -지 않아(요). Often translates as "you know..." or "obviously..." in English.

Meaning: I meant to... but (intention vs. result)

Grammar:
• AVst(는,ㄴ)다는 것이 ____ (result/mistake)

Usage: Used when the speaker's original intention or plan resulted in a different (often negative or mistaken) outcome. The clause usually ends with a description of the mistake or unintended action.

Notes:
• Often contracted to -는다는 게 in spoken Korean.
• Common ending verbs: 잊어버렸다 (forgot), 실수했다 (made a mistake), 잘못했다 (did wrong).

Meaning: Ended up doing, finally did (strong result)

Grammar:
• Vst고 말(었,았,였)다

Usage: Expresses that an action reached an endpoint. It carries a nuance of either: 1. Regret: Something unplanned or undesirable happened (ended up doing...). 2. Achievement: Something difficult was finally accomplished after effort.

Meaning: You see, it's because (providing information)

Grammar:
• Vst거든요.
• N(이)거든요.

Usage: Used to provide a reason or background information that the listener likely does not know. It can respond to a question "Why?" or simply add explanation to a previous statement.

Notes:
• Intonation is key; rising intonation can imply you are waiting for the other person to respond.
• Unlike -잖아요 (shared knowledge), this assumes new information.

Meaning: For fear that, worried that

Grammar:
• Vst(을,ㄹ)까 봐 ___(worried/preventative action)___

Usage: Expresses concern that the action in the first clause might happen, so the speaker performs the action in the second clause (or feels an emotion) to prevent or address it.

Notes:
• Often followed by 걱정이다 (worried) or 조심했다 (was careful).

Meaning: I heard that... (recalling hearsay to introduce topic)

Grammar:
• AVst(는,ㄴ)다고 하던데 ____
• DVst다고 하던데 ____
• N(이)라고 하던데 ____

Usage: The speaker recalls something they heard from others to introduce a topic, ask a question, or confirm a fact. "I heard [fact], is that true?" or "I heard [fact], so let's do this."

Meaning: As soon as, immediately after

Grammar:
• AVst는 대로 ____

Usage: Indicates that the second action occurs immediately upon the completion of the first action.

Notes:
• Similar to -자마자 but often used in future/imperative contexts (e.g., "Call me as soon as you arrive").

Meaning: Worth doing, doable, understandable

Grammar:
• N(은,는,이,가) AVst(을,ㄹ) 만하다

Usage: 1. Recommendation: The value is sufficient to justify the action (e.g., "This movie is worth watching"). 2. Possibility/Justification: The situation is understandable or "just bearable."

Notes:
• Used for recommendations (추천).
• Can imply something is "just okay" or bearable (그저 그렇다 / 참을 만하다).

Meaning: Not only... but also

Grammar:
• Vst(을,ㄹ) 뿐만 아니라 (N)도 ____
• Vst(었,았,였)을 뿐만 아니라 (N)도 ____

Usage: Used to add information. The first clause and second clause should be of the same "weight" or tone (both positive or both negative).

Notes:
• If there is a noun in the second clause, you must use (N)도.
• The left and right of the phrase are 비슷한 사이즈/도가든 느낌 (similar nuance/direction).
• Often used like this: Vst(었,았,였)을 뿐만 아니라 (N)도 AVst(어,아,여)서 ____.

Meaning: Are you saying that...? You mean...? (Reconfirmation)

Grammar:
• AVst(는,ㄴ)단 말이에요?
• DVst단 말이에요?
• Vst(었,았,였)단 말이에요?
• N(이)란 말이에요?

Usage: Used to reconfirm what the other person said, often expressing surprise or disbelief. It asks for clarification by restating the heard information.

Meaning: (Do A) and then (use result for B)

Grammar:
• N(을,를) AVst1(어,아,여)다가 AV2

Usage: Indicates an action is performed on an object, and then that object is moved or used in a subsequent action (e.g., cooking food and then packing it).

Notes:
• N은 눈에 보이는 물건만 써야 된다 (N must be a tangible/visible object).
• `다가`에 `가다`랑 `오다`가 이미 있어서 AVst로 쓰지 말다 (Do not use with 가다/오다 as the first verb, as they have their own -다가 forms).

Meaning: Often do, strictly habitually do

Grammar:
• ~에,~때 AVst곤 하다
• ~에,~때 AVst곤 했다

Usage: Expresses a habit or something that is done repeatedly.

Notes:
• 자주 하는 행동 (Action done often).
• `자주` 쓰지 마 (Do not need to use the word "jaju" explicitly as the grammar implies it).

Meaning: While, during the time that

Grammar:
• AVst는 사이에 ____ (Present action)
• AVst(은,ㄴ) 사이에 ____ (State/Result)

Usage: Indicates that a second action happens within the duration of the first action or state.

Notes:
• The first half is usually first person (context dependent, but often implies "While I was doing X...").
• The second half is always a different subject to the first (e.g., "While I slept, my friend left").
• 보통 짧은 시간 (Usually implies a shorter duration compared to -동안).

Meaning: Pretend to, act as if

Grammar:
• AVst는 척하다
• AVst(은,ㄴ) 척하다 (Past/State)
• DVst(은,ㄴ) 척하다
• N인 척하다

Usage: Used when acting or behaving as if something is true when it actually is not.

Meaning: If (conditional)

Grammar:
• Vst거든 ____ (Command/Suggestion)

Usage: A conditional form used to state "If X happens..." followed by a request, command, suggestion, or promise.

Notes:
• The first half is an if/when clause.
• The second half is a command, suggestion, or promise. (Declarative sentences cannot follow).

Meaning: Because... (and for other reasons)

Grammar:
• (N도) Vst고 해서 ____

Usage: Used to state a primary reason for an action while implying there are other reasons that are not explicitly mentioned. "Partly because of A (and other things), I did B."

Notes:
• First half: there are many reasons but you only want to state the most important one.
• Requires existence of 2+ reasons contextually.
• Don't use a command in the second half.

Meaning: (You) should have... / Why didn't (you)...

Grammar:
• AVst지.
• AVst지 말지. (For negative action)

Usage: Used to express regret or mild criticism that someone did not do something (or did something they shouldn't have). It is a short form of -지 그랬어요.

Notes:
• Different from AVst(어,아,여)야지 (which means "must/will").
• Equivalent to: "Why didn't you...?"

Meaning: I suppose/expect..., it is probably...

Grammar:
• Vst(을,ㄹ) 텐데요.

Usage: Expresses the speaker's strong supposition or expectation about a future or current situation. Often acts as the background for a suggestion or expression of worry (when not at the end of a sentence: -을 텐데...).

Meaning: Just because... (doesn't mean)

Grammar:
• AVst(는,ㄴ)다고 해서 ____
• DVst다고 해서 ____
• Vst(었,았,였)다고 해서 ____
• N(이)라고 해서 ____

Usage: Used to indicate that a certain fact or hearsay does not necessarily lead to a specific result. Often followed by a negative or contrasting clause (e.g., "Just because it's expensive doesn't mean it's good").

Notes:
• Commonly followed by patterns like -는 것은 아니다 (it is not the case that...).

Meaning: Did... but then (change of state/contrast)

Grammar:
• AVst(었,았,였)다가 ____

Usage: Indicates that one action was completed, and then a contrary or related action took place, usually resulting in a return to the original state or a sudden change. (e.g., "I went to the store [and arrived/finished going] but came back").

Notes:
• Contrasts with basic -다가 (interruption of action) because the first action is completed here.

Meaning: It might, it's possible that

Grammar:
• Vst(을,ㄹ) 수도 있다
• Vst(었,았,였)을 수도 있다
• N일 수도 있다

Usage: Expresses possibility. "It is possible that..." or "It could be that..." Used when the speaker acknowledges a potential outcome, even if unlikely.
